title: Trojan:JS/CoinMiner in npm files
content:
Hello,
I am a front end developer and use Vue.js and Visual Studio Code and have had an issue recently with scripts not running in my terminal so decided to fault find.
All programmes that I can think of are up to date, and today I decided to do a full windows defender scan and found the above file.
I cannot say how to reproduce it as I'm not sure how I got it in the first place.
These are my global packages:
PS C:\web-dev\adp-run> npm list -g --depth 0 C:\Users\mada7\AppData\Roaming\npm +-- @vue/cli@3.11.0 +-- @vue/cli-upgrade@3.9.0 +-- core-js@3.2.1 +-- eslint@5.7.0 +-- firebase-tools@7.3.0 +-- git@0.1.5 +-- json-server@0.15.0 +-- netlify-cli@2.12.0 +-- npm@6.11.2 -- serve@10.1.1`
I’ve done some research and cant find what npm package the file came from (if any) so was wondering if :
I) This file is from a compromised npm package I’ve used?
II) This file is from node.js? I’ve done a fresh install of node within the last 7 days
III) Whether I’m one of many infected with this malware, I am not aware of using the event-stream package that was infected previously
Thanks for any help, Windows Defender tells me the threat is blocked.
Adam
Impact
This threat can perform a number of actions of a malicious hacker's choice
steps: Run a full Windows Defender scan on your system to detect the presence of the Trojan:JS/CoinMiner.
Check the global npm packages installed on your system using the command `npm list -g --depth 0` to identify potential sources of the malware.
vuln_description: The vulnerability involves the presence of a Trojan:JS/CoinMiner in npm files, which can perform malicious actions as chosen by a hacker. The malware was detected by Windows Defender, but its exact source (whether from a compromised npm package or node.js) is unclear.
reason: The discovery difficulty is low because the vulnerability was detected by a standard Windows Defender scan, which is a routine security measure. The malware's presence does not involve complex interactions or multiple components, making it straightforward to identify once the scan is performed.
